headline: America is having a break with reality on tariffs. The world will move on to a new order - ABC News
context: The Australian government after May 3 will no doubt want to try to negotiate with the Trump administration about our 10 per cent tariff, but they might be better off to just work around it and move on.
The American age is coming to an end after 80 years and nine months and will be replaced by something that may be better.

annotations.paragraph: We don't yet know what that new world looks like, and the journey there is likely to be painful, especially for America.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the uncertainty and potential challenges of the transition to a new global order.

annotations.paragraph: But the train has left the station — not just because of the tariffs unveiled on April 2, but because Donald Trump has smashed the global system of alliances and co-operation, led by the United States, that has been in operation since the Bretton Woods Conference of July 1944.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers specific information about the impact of Trump's policies on global alliances.

annotations.paragraph: The US government is now having a kind of break with reality.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct commentary on the current state of the US government.

annotations.paragraph: The Trumpists are not even right-wing or conservative in the normal sense, just tribal, recklessly macho and inept.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers an opinion on the nature of Trump's supporters, which is not directly related to the main premise.

annotations.paragraph: What's more, Americans knew who they were voting for last year because they watched him for four years, and then he reminded them last year who he was and told them what he was going to do in his second term.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides background on Trump's re-election, which is not directly relevant to the main topic of tariffs and global order.

annotations.paragraph: They voted for him anyway and now their prices will rise because of the tariffs, many of them will lose their jobs because of the recession and their retirement savings will shrink because of the stock market decline, caused by the combination of uncertainty and the coming stagflation.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific consequences of the tariffs, contributing to the narrative of economic impact.

annotations.paragraph: Most governments, including Australia's, are trying to decide whether to, and how to, bargain with Trump to get their tariff removed, but perhaps they shouldn't bother.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the strategic considerations of governments in response to tariffs, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: First, they are arguing against a mist of fabrication.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is vague and does not provide specific information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Australia can't agree to drop its 10 per cent tariff on American imports because it doesn't exist.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a specific fact that challenges a misconception about tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: The same applies to most, if not all, of the other "reciprocal" tariffs Trump has imposed.
annotations.reason: This paragraph extends the previous fact to a broader context, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: For example, Botswana's tariff is 37 per cent, half of the 74 per cent tariff that it supposedly has on imports from America, but that was calculated by simply taking the $US300 million ($501 million) trade deficit the US had with Botswana in 2024 as a percentage of Botswana's total exports to the US ($US405 million — most of which is diamonds), which is 74 per cent.
annotations.reason: Provides specific data and context about tariffs, relevant to the discussion on tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Botswana does have tariffs on imports from the US, mainly meat and offal, and none of them is more than 40 per cent. The average would be no more than 10 per cent.
annotations.reason: Offers specific information about Botswana's tariffs, relevant to the tariff discussion.

annotations.paragraph: In other words, there is nothing to negotiate. Trump's calculation simply assumes that any deficit must be the result of trade barriers, even though, in the case of Botswana, America has no diamond industry and must import them.
annotations.reason: Directly critiques the logic behind tariff calculations, relevant to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: A trade deficit is usually the result of an exporters' competitive advantage and low income, so it can't afford to buy much of what America sells.
annotations.reason: Provides general economic context about trade deficits, relevant to the discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Countries like Botswana don't have a lot of options except to allow the currency to depreciate, look for other markets, like Europe, and suffer a big hit to economic growth.
annotations.reason: Discusses potential economic impacts and strategies, relevant to the broader context of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: That's why the American tariffs will cause a global downturn: European employment will be hit by a wave of cheap imports and countries that have relied on exports to the US will either have a foreign exchange crisis like in 1998, or a recession, or both.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific consequences of American tariffs, contributing to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: The second thing is that Trump's demands won't be confined to trade.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a new aspect of Trump's policy approach, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: He wields tariffs as an all-purpose weapon to get other countries to do his bidding because he sees all negotiations as nothing more than expressions of power and competitive bullying. The tariffs in January on Mexico, Canada and China were largely designed to stop fentanyl and illegal immigrants coming into the US.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Trump's use of tariffs beyond trade, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: And third, the tariffs are based on a mistaken view of how the economics of modern trade works.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a critique of the economic rationale behind the tariffs, relevant to the article's analysis.

annotations.paragraph: Trump thinks that since imports are subtracted from GDP, they represent a minus, or a loss. But imports also get added to consumption and investment, so they have to be subtracted so you only measure gross domestic product.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains a specific economic misunderstanding by Trump, relevant to the article's critique.

annotations.paragraph: He also thinks that if you stop something being imported, it will magically get made in America instead and lead to more employment.
annotations.reason: This paragraph critiques a belief about tariffs and employment, relevant to the article's theme on tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Leaving aside the fact that manufacturing no longer employs human beings, only robots, that view misunderstands the complex network of supply chains that now constitute global manufacturing.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on global manufacturing, relevant to the discussion on tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Every complex product, such as cars and smart phones, comes out of an intricate global ecosystem, while simple ones like toys and clothes are just a matter of competitive advantage, which can't be wished away.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the global supply chain, relevant to the article's focus on tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: It's impossible to overstate the revolution that Donald Trump has brought about 11 weeks into his second term.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is vague and does not provide specific information related to tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Just six months ago, markets were on about "American exceptionalism", obsessed with the booming "Magnificent 7" companies (Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta Platforms, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Tesla). Its economy, stock market and technology leadership were the envy of the world.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides background on the U.S. economy but is not directly related to the main topic of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Now, the largest US bank, JP Morgan, puts the odds of a US recession at 60 per cent, the Magnificent 7 have dropped 26 per cent, the overall stock market has fallen back to where it was a year ago and stories appear daily about how China is beating the US at its own technology game, including electric vehicles, drones, AI and robots.
annotations.reason: Provides current economic indicators and competition with China relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Perhaps "Liberation Day" can be seen as the world being liberated from America.
annotations.reason: Vague generalization without specific information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Carousel
annotations.reason: Single word with no context or information.

annotations.paragraph: The great American cultural and economic hegemony that has lasted for more than 80 years is coming to an end.
annotations.reason: Directly relates to the article's premise about the end of American dominance.

annotations.paragraph: America's global economic leadership was formalised in 1944, when 730 delegates from 44 allied nations met at the Mount Washington Hotel, in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, and agreed to base the global trading system on the US dollar, which would in turn be pegged to gold.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context for America's economic leadership relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: The gold peg was broken in 1971, but if anything, that made the US dollar, and the United States, even stronger, especially after the collapse of the Soviet Union 18 years later.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context about the US dollar's strength, which is not directly related to the main premise about tariffs and the new world order.

annotations.paragraph: American leadership promoted the spread of free trade, which in turn produced seven decades of rising prosperity in the US and the world, bringing billions out of poverty.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers background on American leadership and free trade, but it doesn't directly address the current issue of tariffs or the new world order.

annotations.paragraph: But Trump is stuck in the idea that trade, and everything else, is a zero-sum game, that for every winner there is a loser and there is no such thing as a win-win, which is how most people approach a negotiation.
annotations.reason: This paragraph directly addresses Trump's perspective on trade, which is relevant to the article's focus on tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: The Soviet Union took 10 years to end, starting with the strike at the Gdansk shipyard in 1980 and the rise of Solidarity, the trade union, and its leader Lech Walesa, and then suddenly with the fall of the Berlin Wall on November 9, 1989.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context about the Soviet Union, which is not directly related to the main topic of tariffs and the new world order.

annotations.paragraph: The first election of Trump in 2016 could be seen as the Gdansk shipyard strike. In that analogy, "Liberation Day", April 2, 2025, was the fall of the Berlin Wall.
annotations.reason: This paragraph draws an analogy between Trump's election and historical events, which is relevant to the narrative of a changing world order.

annotations.paragraph: After November 9, 1989, it took Eastern Europe a long time to figure out what to do with itself, and it took the rest of the world a while to come to terms with the end of the Cold War and having one superpower instead of two.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context about global power shifts, which is relevant to the article's theme of changing world order.

annotations.paragraph: And now, 36 years later, we're back to two, with one flailing and self-harming and the other, China, disciplined and rising fast.
annotations.reason: This paragraph directly relates to the article's premise by discussing the current global power dynamics between the US and China.

annotations.paragraph: Alan Kohler is finance presenter and columnist on ABC News and he also writes for Intelligent Investor.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is biographical information about the author and does not contribute to the article's main story.

annotations.paragraph: Having trouble seeing this form? Try this link.
annotations.reason: This is a technical note unrelated to the article's content.
